abstracts.cdata!:
The general objectives of the project
            were partially met, with a wide variation in performance
            between components, making overall ranking difficult. The
            overall assessment of the project's outcome is
            marginally unsatisfactory. The key lessons learned are: 1)
            Targeted interventions are effective tools for reaching
            vulnerable populations. 2) To maximize impact, investments
            must take into consideration medium-term aspects related to
            sustainability. 3) Even with laudable objectives, the
            success of a project rests on implementation arrangements.
            4) The informal sector is an extremely important part of the
            Chadian economy, especially among the most vulnerable
            populations. 5) Creating services to support the informal
            sector and micro-enterprise will require a long-term
            commitment to designing demand-responsive interventions,
            building institutional capacity, and creating a conducive
            regulatory and legal framework. 6) Within the health sector,
            cost recovery strategies at the primary and secondary levels
            are a viable and attractive option for improving the
            utilization of health centers and quality of service
            delivery, if matched with reliable supply of affordable
            essential drugs. 7) Large-scale urban infrastructure
            investments are best implemented within integrated urban
            development programs. 8) Without a Government agency
            designated for the definition and coordination of social
            policies, studies analytical work and policy formulation is
            best carried out with the ministries.
